Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The Emergence and Evolution of Forced Migration Routes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With more than 65.3 million forced migrants worldwide, global displacement is at an all-time high. Most of the displaced are located in states adjacent to their countries of origin, primarily in the Middle East or Africa. One of the characteristics of contemporary displacement is that these countries of first asylum host the majority of refugees, who often live in limbo in camps or urban centers for years, while richer states keep refugees and migrants at arms' length through policies of deterrence and border control. However, from 2014 through 2016 more than one million migrants reached Europe via the Balkan land route, breaching "Fortress Europe" in unprecedented fashion. This mass migration has far reaching impacts for the stability of the European Union and the lives of millions of refugees and migrants. Yet, almost no empirical research has been conducted on the route, leaving open questions about how the route was forged and the role of refugees themselves in its creation. These questions can only be answered through ethnographic fieldwork while many of the key actors and sites remain in place along the route. This research takes place in the context of the largest global forced migration since World War II. Findings will be disseminated to aid organizations that explore and manage the causes, consequences, and complexities of mass migration. The research also fosters international scientific cooperation, and will train undergraduate students in methods of anthropological data collection and analysis.

This RAPID award supports fieldwork in Egypt, Greece, Serbia, and Germany - countries of departure, transit, and destination - to understand mobility along the Balkan route. The investigators, Drs. Nadia El-Shaarawi and Maple Razsa of Colby College, have longstanding relationships with migrants and refugees from the Middle East, as well as networks along the route, which will allow them to gain access to sites that might otherwise be clandestine and inaccessible. Through participant observation and interviews at sites that have been crucial to recent migrant mobility, sites where migrants and humanitarian workers come together, the researchers will study the forms of negotiation and struggle that made the route possible. Further, they will investigate how migrants experience and manage efforts to restrict their movement. A focus on the route itself, and the ways that refugees and migrants sustained mobility within networks along the route, will provide an empirical alternative to analyses of refugees as victims as well as a methodological tendency to study refugees in place. Such an approach will shed light on how migrant mobility itself is organized, sustained, and curtailed. While the ongoing crisis is unique in scale, an understanding of its social complexity can inform our knowledge of other, similar processes of migration and displacement in the U.S. and worldwide. With the number of refugees only increasing globally, displacement remains a topic of important social and political concern.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project is an ethnography of the Balkan Route, the route traveled by more than a million migrants in 2015-2016 to reach Northern and Western Europe. Based on fieldwork from 2016-2019, the project investigates: 1) the forms the route took; 2) mobility along the route; and 3) how mobility was facilitated and supported by social movements and migrants themselves.

We asked the following research questions:

1)    How do people travel along the route, with particular attention to key sites (e.g. border crossings, informal camps, refugee squats) and modes of clandestine and commercial transportation (e.g. “green” border crossings, busses, ferries)?

2)    What relationships enable (or constrain) mobility along the route, including a) relationships between migrants and others (e.g. activist networks, smugglers, NGOs, state actors); and b) relationships between migrants themselves (e.g. groups of different national origin, kin networks, political organizations)?

3)    How do migrant rights activists attempt to support migrants’ travel along the route, whether through facilitating their movement, public advocacy, or helping them to stay at various sites along the route?

To answer these questions, we conducted fieldwork in key sites along the route, including Greece, Macedonia, Serbia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, and Germany. We interviewed people on the move (i.e. refugees and migrants, regardless of legal status) and activists as well as conducted participant observation at sites including social movement networking events. We have found that regional and local histories of migration and activism were central to both the opening of the route and efforts to resist its closure (El-Shaarawi and Razsa 2019). Unlike most popular accounts, which argue that the opening of the route was a result of policy, specifically Angela Merkel’s willingness to suspend the Dublin Regulation (which stipulates that asylum-seekers must apply in the first EU country they reach), our research has found that people on the move, supported by European activists, have been central to how the Balkan Route was transformed from a clandestine migration route into an open one, briefly disrupting the EU border regime. We have also found that once the borders were successively re-imposed in 2016, people on the move and activists shifted some of their activities from supporting mobility to working for “the right to stay” as part of larger struggles for “freedom of movement.”

Our book manuscript in progress analyzes the transnational route, and its place in struggles for freedom of movement, in more depth. The project, with its focus on a route that spans multiple countries and was traveled by people of many nationalities, differs from many studies of refugees and migration which typically focus on particular communities on one or both sides of a single border or, if studying transnational migration, on following the mobility of people of one ethnic or national identity. Second, the project brings together the literature on social movements and mobility in novel ways, harnessing both senses of “movement” to provide an account of migration and organizing that is often absent.

Broader Impacts

This project applies anthropological methods and theories to a topic of global importance. The mass migration that has occurred beginning in 2014 represents the largest global forced migration since the end of World War II. While the ongoing “crisis” is unique in scale, an understanding of its social complexity can inform our knowledge of other, similar processes of migration and displacement. With the numbers of refugees only increasing globally, displacement remains a topic of important social and political concern.

A second broader impact relates to disseminating scholarly research and collaborating with scholars based in the countries along the route. This collaboration has occurred at both the fieldwork and dissemination stages. We remain committed to highlighting, and contributing to, the rich scholarship on migration along the Balkan route that has emerged from the region. We have begun and will continue to disseminate the results of our research through communications, reports, and workshops that will be available and accessible to solidarity initiatives and people on the move, among others. A final broader impact of this project is STEM training for undergraduate students in the United States. Both PIs are faculty at an undergraduate institution. As part of this project, we have taught a research lab composed of the PIs and undergraduate research assistants. The undergraduate students were trained in ethnographic methods and had the opportunity to collaborate at most stages of the project including research design, data collection, data analysis, and dissemination. Five of these students went on to conduct fieldwork along the Route, mentored by the PIs. Three of these projects have become senior honors theses, one of which was funded by an REU.
